creditline: Collection of Yvonne and Gabriel P. Weisberg
description: same record as L2004.287.10 cat. 37; crowd of women with church and village in background; gold trim; beige paper; cream mat; dark wood frame with gold trim
medium: Black chalk and charcoal with touches of red and green chalk on tan wove paper
text: Charles Milcendeau's travels frequently took him to districts of France that remained untouched by industrialization and to sites where centuries-old traditions were still deeply ingrained in daily life. One such location was the island of Ouessant, off the tip of Brittany. In Women and Children of Ouessant, families in a fishing village wait anxiously under a lowering sky for the men to return from the sea. The tension in their poses and facial expressions suggests they fear the fishermen are lost at sea.
title: Women and Children at Ouessant
